primary.introduction_text: If you’re experiencing financial difficulty whilst studying you may find the information in this article useful to consider.

rich_text_content.text: You may also wish to contact your student support team to discuss your circumstances.
Support whilst you study

You may be eligible for means tested support towards study related costs such as travel, childcare and internet access if you live in a UK nation. Information on all these funds if they’re relevant to you can be found in Funding for computers, internet and childcare etc.
You can see the full range of financial support offered at Scholarships, bursaries and grants from the OU.
The Open University Students Educational Trust (OUSET)

You may be eligible for a grant towards module fees, travel and child/dependent care costs associated with placements/tutorials/residential schools, set books and the purchase, repair or maintenance of essential IT equipment.

Any student registered with the OU is eligible to apply to the Trust, including students studying outside the UK and postgraduate students. The Trust bases their decision on a set of criteria. Students wishing to apply to the Trust should obtain the application form and the current criteria from the OU Students Association.
OU Student Budget Account

If you have set up an OUSBA account and are experiencing difficulties keeping up with the monthly instalments you should contact OUSBA immediately by telephone on +44 (0)300 303 7444 or +44 (0)1908 655 777, or online using the contact form.
Apprenticeships

Funding for an apprenticeship is different in each nation and there are expectations about the support an employer provides. This means other bursaries, scholarship and loans may not be available to you.
However, if you are no longer employed at the organisation you had your apprenticeship with, contact us to discuss alternative study and finance options.
Further resources
For impartial advice about managing your finances outside of your studies, these external organisations offer a range of resources and support.

node.title: Course Grant: Wales
node.description: Eligibility and how to apply for a Welsh course grant.
node.keywords: grant, student finance, repay, borrow, owe, apply, application, eligibility, funding your studies, Wales, Welsh, study-related costs, pay for books, stationery, pay for travel.

rich_text_content.text: Eligible students can apply for a Course Grant to help pay for study-related items such as books, stationery or travel.
A Course Grant is only applicable to students who are continuing to study a qualification which began between 1 September 2014 and 1 September 2018.
Course Grants:
are non-repayable
could be worth as much as £1,155
are available through Student Finance Wales (SFW)
are available if you're studying modules totalling at least 60 credits
you can only receive one Course Grant in each Seasonal Academic Year, regardless of how many 30 or 60 credit modules you study.
How to apply
You can apply online by completing the Part-Time Tuition Fee Loan and Course Grant application form. The quickest and easiest way is by using the Student Finance Wales (SFW) online portal.
SFW will confirm the amount of Course Grant you're entitled to and this will be paid by them directly into your bank account, usually within 4-6 weeks of your module start date.
You don't have to apply for a Part-Time Tuition Fee Loan to be eligible to apply for a Course Grant.
Funding for study-related costs
If you're experiencing financial hardship and have study-related costs, additional support is also available through Funding for study-related costs.

primary.introduction_text: Students in England, Scotland and Wales may be able to apply for a reduction in their Council Tax. If you live in Northern Ireland, you may be eligible for Rate Relief.

rich_text_content.text: If you live in England, Scotland or Wales you may be able to apply for a reduction in your Council Tax if you're taking part in distance learning that requires 21 or more hours of study a week. Your local council will provide detailed advice about your eligibility and how to apply.
Gov.UK has more information about Council Tax Reduction.
If you're applying for a student discount or exemption from Council Tax and you need evidence of your Open University (OU) study, we'll provide you, on request, with a statement certifying:
that you're registered for study
the name of your qualification
the start and end date of the module(s) you're currently registered on; and
the expected number of study hours for that level of study*.
*Note: This is based on an expectation that OU students will study for an average of eight hours per week for each 30 credits of study.
To request a statement you can:
contact Student Recruitment on +44 (0)300 303 5303
email general-enquiries@open.ac.uk
use our Virtual Assistant (Q-Bot) by selecting 'Start request now'.
It’s your responsibility to notify your local council or social security office if:
you cease to be a student
you change your study intensity
there is any other change in your circumstances which may affect your eligibility.
If you live in Northern Ireland you may be eligible for Rate Relief if you're a part-time student or in other specified circumstances.
Visit NI Direct Housing Benefit and Rate Relief for students for more details or contact your local Social Security Office.
If you're applying for part-time student Rate Relief and you need evidence of your Open University (OU) study, we'll provide you, on request, with a statement certifying:
that you're registered for study
the name of your qualification
the start and end date of the module(s) you’re currently registered on
the expected number of study hours for that level of study. This is based on an expectation that OU students will study for an average of eight hours per week for each 30 credits of study.
To request a statement, contact our office in Belfast - email northern-ireland@open.ac.uk or telephone +44 (0)28 9032 3722.
It’s your responsibility to notify your local council or social security office if:
you cease to be a student
you change your study intensity
there's any other change in your circumstances which may affect your eligibility.

node.title: Open University Student Budget Account
node.description: Pay for your study in instalments as you go with an Open University Student Budget Account.
node.keywords: pay, instalments, pay as you go, budget account. OUSBA, open university student budget account, register now pay later, pay by instalments

primary.introduction_text: The Open University Student Budget Account Ltd (OUSBA) is a convenient way to pay your course fees, subject to your individual circumstances. When you enrol with us, you’ll be offered the opportunity to pay your fees through a study loan from OUSBA.

rich_text_content.text: If you choose to pay this way, OUSBA pays your fees to The Open University on your behalf, and you repay OUSBA either in a single sum or in monthly instalments, as you prefer.
You can repay OUSBA at any time before the course begins. In this case, there’s no interest. We call this option ‘register now, pay later.’

Alternatively, you can repay OUSBA in monthly instalments payable over up to a year. In this case, interest does apply from the date the course starts. The interest rate is calculated on the amount you borrow and is fixed for the duration of the agreement, current representative APR 5.1%. We call this ‘paying by instalments.’
An OUSBA agreement is a legally binding credit agreement between you and OUSBA Ltd. By signing this agreement you'll be liable for the repayments in accordance with its terms and conditions.
As a responsible lender, every application made to OUSBA undergoes an affordability check to ensure you can meet your financial obligations.
Many students find OUSBA to be a convenient ‘pay as you go’ option.
Joint loan applications

If you feel you would be unable to obtain an OUSBA loan on your own due to credit history or affordability issues, OUSBA offers the option to apply for a joint loan application with a third party, i.e. husband, wife, partner, parent, sibling, friend etc. In such cases, OUSBA will be required to carry out additional affordability checks separately and/or collectively for both joint applicants who will be jointly and severally liable for loan repayments. Representative APR 5.1%.

As additional affordability checks are required when processing joint loan applications, unfortunately, an instant decision cannot be given. On average the processing time for a joint loan application is five working days from receipt of the required documentation.
Postgraduate loans

OUSBA also offers loans for postgraduate modules, subject to affordability. If you are eligible for a government-funded postgraduate loan or grant, OUSBA may be able to take this into account for income and affordability purposes when making a Postgraduate Loan application. You can discuss your requirements with our representative when you enrol on your chosen course of study.
Find out more
If you want to change your payment method you'll need to contact Student Recruitment who can discuss alternative ways to pay and explain what next steps you need to take.

node.title: Restrictions and issues
node.notes: This page is part of a set of pages called 'Studying more than one module' which is a guided journey and are meant to be viewed together. The first page of the set is in the IA and searchable but this page and the others are not. This is so that students are introduced to the set of pages and their purpose before viewing the separate pages.

rich_text_content.text: Starting studying in February or April

The main start date for OU modules is October but some modules also have start dates in February or April. The modules are, however, mostly Stage 1 modules so you're likely to find that you won’t be able to continue on a February start pattern. In addition, there are fee and funding limits to take into consideration depending on where you live and how you fund your studies. These tend to affect students more when they begin their studies in February and to a smaller extent in April.
Watch the video for an overview of what to think about if you're planning to start studying in February.

video_transcript.text: Most undergraduate modules at the Open University start in October each year. However, some OU modules, mainly level 1 and Access modules, also have other start dates.
If a module has an additional start date to choose from, this will usually be in February.
If you choose to study in February, you should carefully consider how this fits in with your overall study plans.

The key thing to note is that most modules at level 2 and 3, and even some at level 1, only offer an October start date, so you may not be able to continue on a February study pattern throughout your qualification.
And, depending on where you live and the funding arrangements available to you, starting your study with the OU in February may affect the number of credits you can study the following October.
You might also want to take into consideration any summer plans when taking on study starting in February, as you’ll be studying through the summer months.
If you plan to study at full-time intensity, you may want to stagger your credits at level 1 across February and October.
This gives you a gentler start, instead of starting at full-time intensity straight away.
You could study an Access module - where you get an introduction to OU study and explore where your interests lie – and then start your first level one module in October.
But - you’ll need to be prepared to go without a long  break  between those modules.

While the option to study in February (or any presentation other than October) can be a good one in certain situations, we would always recommend talking your plans over with your Student Support Team. We’ll do everything we can to help you make a choice that is best for your study goals.
For more information on planning your study, visit the Help Centre at help.open.ac.uk.

rich_text_content.text: Funding and finance

If you're paying an England, Wales or Northern Ireland fee, the date you start studying towards a qualification determines what is known as your Seasonal Academic Year (SAY). If you start studying in February, your SAY will run from January to December, meaning the fee cap you're subject to in England or funding caps you’re subject to in Wales and Northern Ireland apply to this period.

If you pay an England fee, and you start your study with 120 credits toward a qualification in February, you can't then study any further modules in October of that year. This is due to a cap on the amount of fees we can charge you in a SAY. For most qualifications, this would mean waiting until the following October to do any more study. So a year's break from study.

If you receive maintenance funding from Student Finance in England (for students with a disability) you should also consider the impact your SAY will have on your maintenance funding. You will not be eligible for any further maintenance funding, until you begin studying in a new SAY.

If you pay a Wales or Northern Ireland fee, there is a cap on the amount of funding you can receive from Student Finance in a SAY. This does depend on your circumstances, but you might find that, if you start your studies with 120 credits toward a qualification in February, and are receiving funding from Student Finance, you will not be eligible for any further maintenance funding, until you begin studying in a new SAY (this includes Course Grants in Northern Ireland). You can register for additional modules in October, but you may need to cover any shortfall by another means such as self-funding.

If you are an undergraduate student paying a Scottish, International, or European fee or if you are not studying towards a qualification, the rules around Seasonal Academic Year will not apply to you. However you still won’t usually be able to continue beyond Stage 1 on a February start pattern. We would therefore still encourage you to think about your future plans before starting in February.

An option you could consider is starting 60 credits in February and then a further 60 in October. This does mean, however, that you could be studying without a break for a long time. Staggering this way can also have implications for students who receive Student Finance maintenance payments in England and Wales or Student Finance course grants in Northern Ireland - see more information about staggering your studies further down this page.

Whatever your situation you should contact your Student Support Team (SST) if you are considering starting your studies with more than one module in February or April. Issues around SAY and fee and funding caps are complex and dependent on circumstances and an SST advisor can talk through your plans with you.
Apprenticeship funding means that your modules are fixed at the start of your study and you don't need to register each year.
For more information see Ways to pay your tuition fees and follow the links to your nation.
Clashing schedules

Some OU modules are designed to be studied together but most aren’t. Especially if you're combining two subjects or studying a qualification where there is a lot of choice such as the Open or Combined STEM programmes.

You're likely, therefore, to have two or more TMAs or iCMAs due in one week, clashes in tutorial scheduling and two or more end of module assessments (exams, EMAs or emTMAs) due around the same time. If you're studying more than one module with an exam it’s possible you could have two (or more) exams on the same day.

Identify these ‘pinch points’ in your calendar now. Plot out all your assessment deadlines on a calendar (many students find a large wall-planner helpful, but you can use a paper diary or electronic calendar too). You'll need to be proactive and manage your time carefully around them. Remember that you'll be studying independently. While your tutor(s) and SST are here to support you, it’s you who is responsible for managing your time and ensuring you meet the deadlines.

Also think about your personal ‘pinch points’. There might be particular days, weeks or months at work when you're busier. Things like school holidays, Christmas, family birthdays or a big event such as a wedding might impact on the time you have available for study. Try to plot these on your calendar as well, do any collide with your assessment deadlines?
Progressing from Stage 1 to Stage 2 to Stage 3

It is also worth noting that you may find you need to dedicate more time to your studies as you progress to the next stage. You might, for example, have studied 120 credits successfully at Stage 1 but the module material becomes more complex at Stage 2 and more is expected of you in assessments, so you might find succeeding at more than one module more difficult.
Also note that, from Stage 2, your module grades do count towards your final degree classification.

If you are new to the OU but starting at Stage 2 or Stage 3 because you have transferred credit from elsewhere, do think carefully about whether studying more than one module is right for you. You might give yourself a better chance of success by starting with a single module.
Staggering your modules

Rather than studying two or more modules together from the same start date, another option, on some qualifications at least, is to stagger your modules, for example starting one in October and one in February.

If you’re starting at Stage 1, and the module(s) you want to study is available in February, starting with, for example, a single 60 credit module and then adding another later may give you a better start to your studies. Allowing you to ease yourself in and better understand how demanding studying will be, rather than committing to more credits immediately. As explained above, for most students starting in February who are subject to a SAY, doing 120 credits in February will mean a gap in your studies, so starting with 60 in February, another 60 in October and then continuing your studies the following October will mean you are on course to complete your qualification within the same time-frame.
The downside of staggering your modules, however, is that you will not get a break. In the example above you would be studying for around 18 months with no break.

If you receive maintenance payments from Student Finance you also need to be aware that these are paid based on your SAY. If you stagger your modules across February and the following October, you could be faced with a large gap between when payments end for one SAY and start for another due to the way that the maintenance payment schedule works. See Maintenance loans for students with a disability: England and Maintenance support: Wales for further information and examples.

In Northern Ireland, if you are eligible for a course grant, this is a one-off payment when you start your first module in a SAY. Therefore, if you start your studies in February and receive a Course Grant you will not be eligible to receive an additional grant in October of that year, and as it is unlikely you'll be able to study a further module the following February you will not be eligible to receive another course grant until the following October.
Think about the pros and cons

You need to make sure you've fully thought through your study plans and, if starting in February, discussed it with your SST. Many students assume they can follow a certain study pattern but, whether due to fees and funding reasons or module availability, they cannot. Look ahead to the modules you want to do in the future to check when they are available and familiarise yourself with how your SAY and fees and funding restrictions (if applicable) work. As already mentioned, this is complex, so do talk to your SST.

It might also be helpful to make a list of pros and cons for different options. Limiting yourself to 60 credits a year will give you more time to dedicate to your studies and potentially mean you can achieve higher grades. This does mean it takes you longer to graduate though. You should also consider if the workload you’ll have in certain weeks in your chosen combinations of modules would be a significant barrier to studying any more credits. Think also about different times of year, is it a problem for you not to have a break in the summer?
Revisit the time planner to model how different options will look in terms of demands on your time
The next page might also help you to weigh up the pros and cons by considering your goals and motivations.

node.title: Employer sponsorship
node.description: Your employer may be willing to sponsor you by paying some or all of your fees.
node.keywords: sponsorship form, employer sponsorship, sponsor, eligibility, criteria, funding your studies

primary.introduction_text: Your employer may be willing to sponsor you by paying some or all of your study fees.

rich_text_content.text: Employer sponsorship form
You’ll find the sponsorship form as you go through the online enrolment process after clicking to enrol in Choose your modules on StudentHome.
If you can't find the form when you enrol online or have mislaid the form, you'll need to contact Student Recruitment on +44 (0)300 303 5303.
If you make your reservation over the phone, you can request for your registration pack, which includes the sponsorship agreement form, to be posted to you.

Your employer needs to complete and sign the sponsorship form. It needs to be returned with your registration agreement by your module reservation expiry date. You’ll find the email or postal address to return the forms to on your module registration agreement. If you’ve already registered on a module, and want to change your payment method to sponsorship, you’ll need to do so before your module starts by contacting Student Recruitment on +44 (0)300 303 5303.
The following video is a step-by-step guide that will show you how to enrol on your module if your employer is funding your studies.

video_transcript.text: This video explains how to enrol for an OU module if your employer is funding your studies by sponsorship. Let's get started.
Step one
First, you'll need to log in to your StudentHome. These details would have been sent to you when you made your first module reservation or qualification registration.
On the StudentHome page click 'Track your application progress', then "confirm your registration" on the next page.
Check that you've registered for the correct module and start date and click 'proceed'. Then you'll confirm a few details about yourself and also confirm your email address.
Now you'll see the payment options for your module, which may vary depending on the module and Nation or country you're resident in.

As your employer will be funding your studies, scroll to the bottom of the page and tick the box to say you'll be paying by sponsorship and that your employer should be invoiced. If your employer wants to pay us immediately by card, you can choose the card payment option and you'll be able to make a third-party card payment.
You now have a choice to have your forms posted to you or to download them. Tick the box if you want to have them posted or leave blank if not, then click 'pay later'.

Next we'll ask you to check important information and confirm your fee eligibility, this may vary depending on your country of residence. Once you've read the information click 'proceed' and you'll be on the summary page.
You'll now see a summary of your module and have the option to download and print all your forms.

In order to complete your enrolment by sponsorship you'll need the registration agreement for you to complete, and the sponsorship agreement for your employer to complete. You can post them back to us or complete electronically and email them to us.

You can also download the terms and conditions of registration which you should read prior to enrolment. For more details, view our 'Registration Agreement' video. (Web link on screen - openuniversity.co.uk/how.)
Step two

The sponsorship form summarises the module details and your employer will need to read this form to sign and agree to the sponsorship terms and conditions. The form also has details on where to send once completed. Please note that if you're part paying with sponsorship and card, we can't accept card details via email.
Your sponsor must complete the invoice contact box, these details will appear on the invoice and will also be used if we need to contact them for any reason.
Ensure the purchase order box is completed or N/A can be added if they don't use a purchase order system or one is not required on the invoice.

Next, complete the signature box. We can accept an electronic signature in any PDF format. We can't accept a sponsorship agreement signed by the same person who is studying the module unless you're a sole trader or director. Please indicate here if applicable. (On screen Yes / No next to Are you a sole trader/sole director in the signature box highlighted.)
your sponsor can then complete their organisation details, this is important if they differ from the invoice details.
Step three

When the form is completed please return with your completed registration agreement, as we need both to complete your enrolment. All return details are on the forms. Please ensure these reach us before the Final Enrolment Date.
Once we receive you forms, we'll process them and confirm when enrolment is complete. we'll also contact you or your sponsor if we need to.
Your sponsor will be invoiced within 30 days of your module start date.

Once we've confirmed your enrolment, we'll be with you from day one, helping you discover the huge benefits of online learning. From familiarising you with the best resources available to exploring the amazing study materials on offer, we'll encourage and support you to succeed from the start.
And if you need any help at any point, please get in touch. (Web link on screen - open.ac.uk/contact.)

rich_text_content.text: For more videos to help you with the online registration process see openuniversity.co.uk/how.

node.title: British Forces Enhanced Learning Credits
node.description: If you’re a serving member of the British Armed Forces (or you’ve recently left), then you may be eligible to use Enhanced Learning Credits to pay for your studies.
node.keywords: ELC, enhanced learning credit, british forces, BFPO, Ministry of Defence, armed forces, funding your studies, elcas

primary.introduction_text: If you’re a serving member of the British Armed Forces (or you’ve recently left), then you may be eligible to use Enhanced Learning Credits (ELC) to pay for your studies. Enhanced Learning Credits are used by the Ministry of Defence to sponsor their Armed Forces personnel to improve their education and to support them through the move to civilian life.

rich_text_content.text: There are two types of ELC funding available:

With 100% Publicly Funded Further Education/Higher Education (PF FE/HE), you may receive funding for up to 360 credits of Open University module fees, enabling you to gain an undergraduate qualification (either a foundation degree or full undergraduate degree). To be eligible you must be in your qualifying resettlement phase, studying at least 30 credits each Seasonal Academic Year, meet UK residency requirements and have not already completed an undergraduate qualification or obtained 120 credits or more of higher education study.

With 80% ELC funding, depending on how long you’ve been serving in the Armed Forces, you may be eligible for either the higher tier (up to £2,000) or lower tier (up to £1,000). If you choose to study with us, as your learning provider we'll receive part payment towards the cost of your fees, for up to three Ministry of Defence financial years. The Ministry of Defence pays for up to 80% (within the maximum of £1,000 or £2,000) of your Open University module fees, and you pay the rest (at least 20%).
More detailed information including how to complete your registration if your ELC claim has been approved can be found at Enhanced Learning Credits.
Disabled Veterans' Scholarships Fund
If you’re a disabled armed forces veteran who was injured in or due to military service, you may be eligible to apply for a scholarship. See Disabled Veterans’ Scholarships Fund for more details.

node.title: Job changes and study problems
node.description: Tips to help if changes in your work life are affecting your studies.
node.keywords: Job change, career change, job problems, work problems, work change, problems at work, financial changes, taking a break, study break, Funding, funding difficulties, finance, finance difficulties, financial difficulties, apprentice redundancy

primary.introduction_text: Starting a new job, or increased hours or responsibility at work, can mean you have less time for study, have a change in your financial situation or change your study interests and priorities.

rich_text_content.text: Catch up with study
Be proactive and talk to your tutor for advice on where you should focus your efforts and if there's any material you can leave aside so you can catch up.

You may also find that you don’t need to complete all your assignments, many aren’t compulsory so you may still be able to pass your module if you have to miss one out. This is explained in falling behind with study.
Financial changes

If job changes mean you're worried about paying for your study, do talk things through with your student support team (SST) to check your options. You can also find out more about your payment options in funding and finance difficulties.

If you’re receiving financial support and your income has increased then the funds you’re currently receiving won’t be affected. However future applications may be. If your income has decreased and you’re facing financial hardship you may be able to apply for additional funds. See Scholarships, bursaries and grants from the OU for details of what may be available to you.

If you're an apprentice funding for your apprenticeship is different in each nation and there are expectations about the support your employer provides. This means other bursaries, scholarship and loans may not be available to you. However, if you are no longer employed at the organisation you had your apprenticeship with, contact your student support team to discuss alternative study and finance options.
Careers support

If your employment situation has changed you may benefit from some advice and guidance from our Careers and Employability Services. We have information to help you apply for jobs, there's an online vacancy service, or you can join a forum to talk to other students, careers consultants and employers about trends and opportunities in different sectors. You can also request an individual careers consultation or interview.
If your interests or study goals have changed you could look into changing the modules you're studying or changing to a different qualification. This may not apply if you're an apprentice.
Redundancy

Redundancy can be a life defining and challenging moment, an opportunity to take stock and can lead to positive change and outcomes. Take a look at the our articles on Redundancy which includes a series of podcasts talking you through the impact of redundancy, utilising your experience, strengthening your skills, building your confidence, finding your next role and more. You could also book a one-to-one careers consultation for further guidance.

If you're an apprentice and are facing redundancy or have been made redundant, remember you have employment rights as an employee. Also, your training provider (the OU) needs to make reasonable efforts to find you another employer to enable you to complete your apprenticeship, including in some cases (if you're made redundant within six months of completion) to continue your training without being employed. The Learning and Work Institute have produced a leaflet, A guide to the support available for apprentices, which has more information. You should also talk to your Apprentice Support Team.
Taking a break

If your work is preventing you from studying at the moment you could consider deferring from modules and returning later on when you have more time. Your SST can organise this, but there are some implications you need to read about. If you need to talk to us you can find your tutor and student support team contact details at Contacts.
If you're an apprentice and your job has significantly changed there may be options to take Breaks in learning.

node.title: Funding for apprenticeships
node.description: Find out how apprentices are funded.

primary.introduction_text: The Open University offers a range of apprenticeships in England, Scotland and Wales. The funding arrangements depend on your location.

rich_text_content.text: The way an apprenticeship is funded enables a close collaboration between you, us (the training provider) and your employer. You can find the full range of apprenticeships at Open University Apprenticeships.
You shouldn't incur any study or training costs when studying as an apprentice as this is covered by your employer or your funding organisation.
Apprenticeships are funded by the Apprenticeship Levy meaning the funding agency responsible for apprenticeships in your UK nation will need evidence that you are:
eligible for an apprenticeship, including being in employment
progressing in your apprenticeship
using your paid work time for off-the-job study appropriately
following the funding rules if you need to change your study plans.
These requirements mean there are specific Academic Regulations and Conditions of Registration as an apprentice.
Find out more at Being an OU Apprentice.
Further resources
For a useful guide for apprentices visit the Learning and Work Institute.

node.title: Part-time maintenance loans for students with a disability: England
node.description: If you’ve been prevented from attending a campus-based university due to a disability or medical condition you may be entitled to a maintenance loan from Student Finance.
node.keywords: disability, maintenance loan, support, living costs,

primary.introduction_text: If you’re starting an honours degree which began after 1 August 2018 and have a disability or medical condition that has prevented you from physically attending a campus-based university, you may be eligible for a part-time maintenance loan to support your living costs.

rich_text_content.text: Part-time maintenance loans in brief
apply through Student Finance England (SFE)
award will depend on your study intensity
award will depend on where you live (living at home, outside London, or in London)
means-tested based on household income
applications can take up to 10 weeks, so apply early
loan payments start once we've confirmed your registration, this will be after the 14th day of your module.
You can find out more about the amount you may be eligible for by using the government's finance calculator.
Eligibility
You need to be starting an honours degree which began after 1 August 2018 or topping-up a previously completed lower level qualification to an honours degree.
You’ll need to be studying a module of at least 30 credits (25% intensity) each academic year.
You’ll need to meet the residency criteria for England as defined by Student Finance.
You've looked at studying at a campus-based university, but your disability or medical condition means you are unable to regularly attend.
You've researched and considered a campus-based university and found they could not accommodate your requirements with their reasonable adjustments or additional support.
Your disability or medical condition prevents you from travelling to/from a campus-based university.
Your disability or medical condition results in restricted access to study facilities at a campus-based university.
Evidence you’ll need
Evidence of your disability or medical condition, for example a letter from your GP or consultant which clearly states your condition prevents you from attending a face-to-face university.

Evidence which demonstrates you've researched campus-based universities and found them unable to provide the support adjustments you need for you to attend. For example, email exchanges between yourself and the university.
How to apply
Applications are made through Student Finance England, alongside your Part-time Tuition Fee Loan application.
When you'll receive your loan payments

Once your loan application is approved, your first module has started and you're actively studying, the University will confirm your registration to SFE and you'll receive your payments. The University will not confirm your registration until day 14 of your module has passed. You should not expect to receive your first instalment until at least three weeks after your module has started.
Seasonal Academic Year (SAY) and maintenance loan payments

The date you first start to study towards your qualification (this includes Access modules studied as part of your qualification) will set your initial Seasonal Academic Year. See Seasonal Academic Year for more information on how the SAY is calculated.
Your maintenance funding will be paid in line with the start of the first module within your Seasonal Academic Year. See examples of typical payment schedules in the following table.

primary.csv_data:
First module in your SAY,Seasonal Academic Year/Loan application Year,Typical maintenance payment schedule
February 2022,2021/22,"February 2022, April 2022, August 2022"
April 2022,2021/22,"April 2022, August 2022, January 2023"
October 2022,2022/23,"October 2022, January 2023, April 2023"
February 2023,2022/23,"February 2023, April 2023, August 2023"
April 2023,2022/23,"April 2023, August 2023, January 2024"

rich_text_content.text: Remember you must apply for the correct loan year.

If you start another module within the same Seasonal Academic Year the University will adjust your credits for the year. Afterwards, Student Finance will inform you of your updated maintenance funding entitlement. This could mean an increase to the payment amounts you were due to receive or, if you have already received three scheduled payments for the year, you may receive an additional payment.

If you do not start a module at the same time in the following academic year, your Seasonal Academic Year will change, meaning that your payment schedule will also change. This applies even if you are continuing to study a module which began in the previous SAY. To help you understand what we mean by this, see the following examples:

note_body.text: You started your first module in February 2022 under a Winter 2021/22 SAY, which runs from 1 January to 31 December 2022.
You study another module which starts in October 2022, this module also comes under your 2021/22 SAY.
Typically, in line with the table of payment schedules above, you would have been paid all of your maintenance payments by August 2022 for the 2021/22 SAY.

This means that by the time you start your October 2022 module, you would have already received all your maintenance funding for 2021/22. You wouldn’t be eligible for any more funding until you started a new module which begins in your next SAY.
If you studied another module in February 2023, your Winter SAY study pattern would continue and your next maintenance payment for your 2022/23 SAY would be paid in February 2023.

If you didn’t study in February 2023, and studied your next module in October 2023 instead, your SAY would reset to an Autumn 2023/24 SAY. In this scenario your next maintenance payment would be paid in October 2023.

This change in study pattern could happen either because you choose not to study another module in February 2023, or because there is no availability of a module suitable for your qualification running at that time.

node.title: Using a computer and your wellbeing
node.description: How to stay healthy while studying at a computer or device.
node.keywords: eye fatique, migraine, headache, aches and pains

primary.introduction_text: We all struggle from time to time from the effects of too much screen time. Spending too much time staring at the screen of your computer or other device can cause eye strain and fatigue which can lead to blurred vision, headaches or even migraines. Sitting at a desk for long periods of time to study can also have negative effects on the body if proper precautions aren't taken. This article offers some tips and suggested resources to help you make the right decisions for your wellbeing and comfort when studying.

rich_text_content.text: Reducing eye strain and fatigue
Adjust your settings

One of the first things you could try is adjusting settings on your computer or device. Try adjusting the brightness level of your screen to where it feels most comfortable to you. If the size of the text you are reading is too small, try zooming in or adjusting the text settings on your computer or web browser. You may be able to adjust the screen or text contrast (difference in colour between the text and background) making use of settings such as ‘dark mode’ to ease the strain on your eyes. There are also several apps and browser plug-ins you could try such as ones that will adjust your screen brightness depending on the time of day.
Consider your workspace
How you set up your space can also be important. Here are some tips.
Your computer or laptop screen should be positioned the right distance from your eyes at around an arm's length.
You should ideally be looking slightly down at your screen, eyes level with the top of your screen.
Study in a well-lit room – you may want to use an additional desk light, but make sure lights are not causing screen glare or shining directly into your face.
Work away from windows or close the curtains or adjust the blinds if you find that sunlight creates glare.
Consider using a glare filter for your screen if glare is a persistent problem.

If you're often looking back and forth between print materials and your computer or laptop, you may want to consider using a document stand so that your print materials and computer screen are at the same eye level.
Give your eyes a break
Pay attention to how long you look at your screen. Doing the following might help avoid headaches and eyestrain.
Use the “20-20-20 rule.” Look away from your screen every 20 minutes and concentrate on something 20 feet away for 20 seconds.
Make a study schedule and take regular breaks to give your eyes a rest and to look after your mental and physical wellbeing.
Set timers that will remind you to take a break if you find that you often lose track of time. There are also apps and tools you can download to help with this.
Remember to blink! The best way to reduce dryness in your eye is to blink regularly.
Try different ways of studying

You may find that changing how you are studying makes a difference. Make use of the additional formats available for your module materials such as Ebook versions, or you could try listening to your module materials.
If eye strain, headaches or migraines continue to be a problem

If you are often experiencing problems with your eyes, headaches or migraines you may need to seek expert advice from your optician or GP. It could be that you require reading glasses or need to change your prescription lenses. Your optician or GP may also be able to recommend eye drops or special lenses that reduce screen glare.

If you have declared, or are able to provide evidence, of a disability or health condition that affects your ability to study on a screen you may be able to request adjustments such as printed versions of your online materials. You can also contact the Disability Support team to discuss your needs.
Reduce aches and pains
It's important to find ways and places to study that are comfortable for you. Here are some tips.
Make sure you study in a comfortable chair that gives you the right back support.

If you sit at a desk make sure your set-up is as comfortable as possible, ideally your feet should be flat on the floor and, as you type, your forearms should be horizontal to the floor with your elbows bent at around 90 degrees.
Use a footrest if needed.
If you often study with a laptop from your couch, try using a laptop tray or something underneath your laptop so it is not resting on your legs.
If you have an appropriate space such as a free length of kitchen counter or a high table, you could experiment with standing up to study and work on assignments, if this is comfortable to you.
When using a mobile or tablet to study, try to find a position that will support your back and neck as much as possible.

Try to spread out your study time, but if you do plan to study for a long period of time, over several hours, you should remember to take breaks. Try to take a break at least once an hour. Get up and stretch or go for a walk. Use a timer, such as an alarm on your mobile device or computer to remind you when to take a break.

Also consider the device you are using. Mobile devices such as tablets and e-readers can be useful for reading materials but are likely to cause you discomfort if you are working from them all the time or trying to type an assignment on them. Funding is available, if you meet the eligibility criteria, to help you to purchase a computer. If you live in England, Wales, or Northern Ireland this is through Funding for study-related costs and in Scotland through Discretionary funds for study-related costs. See Funding for computers, internet and childcare etc. for more information.

If you have declared, or are able to provide evidence, of a disability or health condition you may be eligible to request adjustments such as ergonomic equipment or furniture to help you study comfortably. You can also contact the Disability Support team to discuss your needs.
Improve your concentration

When studying on a computer or laptop there are many opportunities to become distracted from study. If you find that this is the case for you, one strategy you could try it is to set up a separate study account on your computer. See Setting up separate accounts on your computer for more information. This may also be useful if you share a computer with other family members and want to keep your study separate.

It’s also important to keep your study documents on your computer or device organised so you don't need to spend time looking around for them. Ensuring you have an effective filing system on your computer or device can help with this. See the How to organise your computer files.

You can also improve your concentration by effectively managing your time whether you are studying on screen of off. See the article Time management skills for some useful tips. You could also try the Plan your time tool. Remember to plan in study breaks especially if you plan to study over a long period of time in one sitting.

Ensuring your friends and family are aware of your study plans and that you will need their support to concentrate and manage your time effectively is also important. The article Friends and family has some useful talking points or you can ask them to have a look at the article themselves.
Take care of your mental wellbeing

Studying a screen can also have in impact on your mental wellbeing. Managing your time, taking breaks and ensuring you get time away from your computer or device can help with this, but at times studying may feel isolating or overwhelming.

There is, however, lots of support available to you, from tips to improve your mental wellbeing, to additional support the OU can offer and how to access professional help. See our Mental health and wellbeing section.

node.title: Student loans for low credit value modules: England, Wales and Northern Ireland
node.description: Financial support for modules of less than 30 credits where the module, residential school or project is compulsory for you to complete your qualification.
node.keywords: modules of less than 30 credits, eligibility, apply, application, fee loan, part time tuition fee loan, lower credit value modules, lower credit

primary.introduction_text: Students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland who are studying a low credit value module (those with less than 30 credits) may be eligible to apply for a student loan. These are called Part-time Tuition Fee Loans.

rich_text_content.text: To be eligible you’ll need to:
have already enrolled on a module(s) of 30 credits or more that begins before or at the same time as the low credit value module, and
be studying the 30 credits or more module(s) in the same seasonal academic year as the low credit value module.
You don't need to have paid for the module(s) of 30 credits or more using a Part-time Tuition Fee Loan.

If you do not begin a module(s) of 30 credits or more you’ll not be able to use a Part-time Tuition Fee loan to pay for the low credit value module and you’ll be asked to pay the fees by a different payment method.
For more details on eligibility see the loan overview articles in Ways to pay.

node.title: Reviewing your career options after module results
node.description: Learn how to think strategically about your results, your study experience and your future career.
node.keywords: module result, module results, fail, failing, failed, reflect, reflecting, reflection, career, module, modules, career goal, career goals, personal goal, personal goals, study goal, study goals, eat, pray, love, personal development planning, career plan, career planning, prospects, futureyou

related_links.related_links_title: When and where to find your module results
What happens if I fail my module?

primary.introduction_text: Well done on completing your module. Getting your results provides you with an opportunity to reflect on how your study is going, check you’re on track with your career and personal goals and plan your next steps. Here are a few things you might want to think about to help you do this.

rich_text_content.text: Identify your achievements, interests, and challenges

Take this chance to reflect on what areas you felt confident with, what challenged you or you didn’t enjoy, and what inspired you to succeed. Record any achievements using FutureYOU, currently being rolled out on qualifications across the OU. Find FutureYOU on the ‘Succeed’ or ‘Plan’ tabs on your Study Home, along with other resources that can support your career and employability aims. If it’s not yet available for your qualification, you may wish to use the Open programme version.

The process of getting to know yourself, what you’re good at and what interests and motivates you is the first step towards planning your future. This will help you match jobs and careers to suit your values, interests and skills. Take a look at the activities in section 01 ‘Know yourself’ of Your Career Planning Guide to help you get started.
If you didn't pass or get the results you wanted

quote_text.text: There is no such thing as failure, only feedback.

rich_text_content.text: Don’t despair. Take this as an opportunity to reflect on what you can learn from this experience to move forward. Remember you’re not alone and there’s plenty of help at hand. To find out what support is available to help you stay motivated, watch our webinar Staying motivated after results.

Keep an open mind when considering future possibilities and don’t discount any avenue without fully exploring it. If you have a very specific career path in mind, research the skills and knowledge you’ll need and compare them with the learning outcomes of your module and/or qualification. This will help you in making decisions about your next steps. If you wish to discuss your plans further contact the careers team.
Discover a wider range of career options

Whether you’re just starting to set career goals, or you’re revisiting previous ones, use Kudos AD, to identify a wide range of options related to your skills, values and interests; there might be some you hadn’t even considered before. Find out how to choose a career that suits you based on your qualifications, skills or what motivates you. Research Careers with your OU Subject and find out what OU students do.
Explore routes into your chosen career

When you’ve got an idea of what you’d like to do, start to identify the qualifications, skills and experience needed. Take a look at the How do I become a … ? page for advice on exploring specific career paths, and start researching job opportunities to get an idea of the labour market and your chosen industry.
You’ve completed your qualification or OU studies, what next?

Congratulations on completing your studies. Your OU journey doesn’t end here, the OU’s Careers and Employability Services is here to support you for up to three years after you've completed your studies. Sign in to OpportunityHub to find out more about the range of careers support on offer. You can also search hundreds of graduate, work experience and volunteer opportunities, follow employers, book live events and arrange one-to-one careers appointments.

node.description: If you can’t find an answer to your computing problem, look here before trying the Helpdesk.
node.keywords: 32bit, 64bit, 32 bit, 64 bit, MSINFO, refworks, write 'n' cite, write'n'cite, refworks group code, Athens, MyReferences, OU Harvard style, gvSig, default Spanish, Sibelius, tech support

rich_text_content.text: There are many issues with computing that you may be experiencing. We've included here some links to The Computing Guide for the most frequently asked and links to the help section for some of the third-party software you may use during your study.
How do I generate a MSinfo file to send to the Helpdesk?

To help our technical team carry out further diagnostics they may ask you to send them a MSinfo (Microsoft information) file. Use the instructions below to create a file that you can save somewhere to easily send to the Computing Helpdesk.
For Windows Vista, Windows 7 and Windows 8:
Use the ‘Start menu’ or ‘Windows logo’ button and type MSinfo32.exe into the ‘Search’ bar
MSinfo32 will then appear at the top of the Start menu.
Double click it to launch the program and save the file
For Windows 10:
Type MSinfo32 into the search box.
Go to the search result which should be System Information.
From the File menu in System Information choose Export and save the file.
The Computing Guide
Some areas of technical help included in the Computing Guide are:

fields.link_list_title: Finding out which version of Windows or Mac you're using

rich_text_content.text: Third-party software
If you're having an issue with third-party software, we recommend you refer to their help guides. We've included some links here that you may find useful:

fields.link_list_title: How to change the default lauguage of gvSIG (YouTube video)

rich_text_content.text: Contact the Computing Helpdesk

It’s worth checking whether the Computing Guide covers the issue before calling the Helpdesk. We would also advise you to check our IT systems status page to see if the issue you’re experiencing is known to us.

The Computing Helpdesk is available 24 hours, 7 days a week, including UK bank holidays. They can help with installing OU software and technical problems running that software. They cannot teach you how to set up and use the software. You should refer to your module materials for this and contact your tutor if you get stuck. Our article asking for help with IT explains more about the Computing Helpdesk and the information they need from you when you contact them.
See Contact us for the Computing Helpdesk contact information.

node.title: Withdrawing from study
node.description: What to do if you’re thinking about stopping your studies.
node.keywords: Withdraw, cancel, quit, break, study break, new framework, old framework, modular, defer, deferring, deferral, postponement, discretionary postponement, extension, leave, leaving, quitting, quitting the OU, leaving the OU, stop studying, stopping studying, giving up
node.audiences: ug-eng-q1, ug-ni-q1, ug-scot-q1, ug-wales-q1, ug-wales-q1-trans, ug-non-uk-q1, apprentice

rich_text_content.text: All students find aspects of their study difficult at times and we understand that you may feel like stopping your studies at some point.
Talk to us first

We advise you to talk to your tutor if you’re considering stopping study, they may come up with some practical tips so you don’t have to stop – for example you may be able to miss out some assignments but still complete the module.
We also offer online resources to help if you’re struggling with study.

If you’re studying towards a qualification which is sponsored by your employer and has a work-based practice element you should talk through the implications of withdrawing with your employer. If you're an apprentice you should read changing your study plans as an apprentice and also contact us to discuss your options.
Financial implications of withdrawing

It’s vital that you tell us if you want to stop studying as you are responsible for paying your Open University (OU) module fees until you formally defer or withdraw from your module. If you formally defer or withdraw you may receive a partial refund or discount off further study. Contact your student support team (SST) to discuss the financial implications of withdrawing from your module. For full information take a look at our Fee Rules

If you have a tuition fee loan from Student Finance England or Student Finance Wales you will still have to repay any loan you have already used and any interest that accrues on it. For more information go to the Student Loans Company website.
Need some time out?

Rather than withdrawing from study completely you could consider stopping studying your current module(s) but continue to be registered on a qualification. You can come back and complete the module at a later date – see take a break from study for more information.

You may not want to come back to your module, in which case you can withdraw and then register on a different module that counts towards your qualification, take a look at changing your modules for more information.

Depending on how far into your module you are, you may be entitled to a partial refund or a discount off further study. For information about any fee refunds or discounts if there's a change in your study plans, take a look at our Fee Rules.

If you have a tuition fee loan from Student Finance England or Student Finance Wales you will still have to repay any loan you have already used and any interest that accrues on it. For more information go to the Student Loans Company website.
Impact on further study
If you withdraw from or fail a module then you’ll still be able to study with us on another module now or in the future.

However, you need to be aware that if you fail or withdraw (and don’t defer your study) from three successive presentations of a module you may be prevented from registering on any further modules. You may also lose any eligibility for financial support. We will warn you after two fails or withdrawals that you may have this problem and advise you further. For more information about this, see the Academic Regulations.
Withdrawing from your qualification
Withdrawing from a qualification means that you stop studying with the OU with no intention of returning to study at a later date. You can withdraw from your qualification at any time.

If you wish to withdraw, speak to your tutor or SST first. If you decide to go ahead with withdrawing with no intention of returning you must notify us formally as detailed in Changing Your Study Plans: Deferrals, Withdrawals and Cancellation – you will not be withdrawn following a conversation with your SST unless you clearly express this is your final decision.
If you do withdraw you will receive an email to confirm you are no longer a student, until you receive this you are still considered to be an OU student.
If you’re sponsored by your employer
If you’re studying towards a qualification which is sponsored by your employer and has a work-based practice element you should talk through the implications of withdrawing with your employer.
